name: Lili Boulanger
bio: Lili Boulanger (1893–1918) was a French composer and the younger sister of Nadia Boulanger. She was the first woman to win the prestigious Prix de Rome for composition in 1913, with her cantata 'Faust et Hélène'. Despite her short life, she created a remarkable body of work, including choral, orchestral, and chamber music. Her music is noted for its rich harmonies, expressive depth, and originality, and she is remembered as a trailblazer for women in composition.

name: Johann Sebastian Bach
bio: Johann Sebastian Bach (1685–1750) was a German composer and musician of the Baroque period, revered for his mastery of counterpoint and harmonic innovation. His works remain foundational to Western classical music.

name: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
bio: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart (1756–1791) was an Austrian composer whose prolific output across symphonies, operas, chamber music, and sacred works made him one of the most influential composers of the Classical era.

name: Maurice Ravel
bio: Maurice Ravel (1875–1937) was a French composer associated with impressionism, though he preferred to be considered a classicist. He was admired for his exquisite orchestration and innovative harmonic language.

name: Iannis Xenakis
bio: Iannis Xenakis (1922–2001) was a Greek-French composer, architect, and mathematician. Known for his groundbreaking use of mathematical models and architectural concepts in music, he created works of radical sonority and structure.

name: Caroline Shaw
bio: Caroline Shaw (b. 1982) is an American composer, violinist, and vocalist. She won the Pulitzer Prize for Music in 2013, becoming the youngest recipient ever. Her works span classical, experimental, and popular music collaborations.

name: Pauline Oliveros
bio: Pauline Oliveros (1932–2016) was an American composer, accordionist, and central figure in experimental and electronic music. She pioneered the practice of 'deep listening,' exploring sound, meditation, and improvisation.

name: Arnold Schönberg
bio: Arnold Schönberg (1874–1951) was an Austrian composer and music theorist, known as the founder of the Second Viennese School. He developed the twelve-tone technique, profoundly shaping 20th-century modernism.

name: Éliane Radigue
bio: Éliane Radigue (b. 1932) is a French electronic composer celebrated for her immersive, slowly evolving works, often created with analog synthesizers and later with acoustic instruments. Her music explores subtle timbral shifts and deep listening.

name: Wendy Carlos
bio: Wendy Carlos (b. 1939) is an American composer and electronic music pioneer, best known for her groundbreaking work with the Moog synthesizer. She brought electronic music to mainstream audiences and composed iconic film scores.
